pullRequest.body:
This fixes a problem I encountered in another tactic, where the rewrites are not being tried with the original `MetavarContext`. 

---

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
The PR description doesn't seem to be accurate anymore (regarding `addRewriteSuggestion`). Could you fix that? Then it seems like these incremental improvements to `rw?` are ready to be merged.

bors d+

:v: semorrison can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  Build succeeded!

  The publicly hosted instance of bors-ng is deprecated and will go away soon.

  If you want to self-host your own instance, [instructions are here][instructions].
  For more help, visit [the forum].

  If you want to switch to GitHub's built-in merge queue, visit [their help page][gh].

  [instructions]: https://github.com/bors-ng/bors-ng#how-to-set-up-your-own-real-instance
  [the forum]: https://forum.bors.tech
  [gh]: https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/configuring-branches-and-merges-in-your-repository/configuring-pull-request-merges/managing-a-merge-queue



  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6006616615/job/16291419837)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6006616615/job/16291420084)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6006616615/job/16291420223)

Is there a reason why it's creating a string representation from scratch rather than doing `let mut tacMsg := m!"{tac}"`? This string version isn't using the result of `delabToRefinableSyntax` for example, and I can't tell if that's intentional or an oversight.
I think this was just an oversight. (Present in the code before this PR, I've just made the same mistake for each element of the list!)

It doesn't really matter here because these are the last things in the `fun`, but in general I think it's nicer to use "dynamic let" versions of setters when they're available since they're easier to reason about:
```suggestion
           withMCtx r.mctx do
              let replaceResult ← goal.replaceLocalDecl f r.result.eNew r.result.eqProof
              replaceMainGoal (replaceResult.mvarId :: r.result.mvarIds)
```
Just to check, the point of having `rewritesCore` take a `MetavarContext` is that `ListM` does not checkpoint it, so you can't have the first line in the `do` be `let ctx <- getMCtx`, right?
That's right. I should add a comment explaining this carefully, as it confused me thoroughly. :-)

There seem to be some failing tests. I didn't spend any time debugging it, but there's a chance that all you need to do is use `addMessageContext` when you pass the massages into `addSuggestion`, since it seems like the problem is that the messages have forgotten the local context they were created in.
Oh, nothing to do with the message: one of the `withMCtx` really needed to be a `setMCtx` (when we're in `!` mode).

Is there a chance that either of the following two things happen in `computeRfl`?
1. since we don't `setMCtx r.mctx`, we might have mvar( assignment)s we don't know about;

2. `.rfl` might assign metavariables in `eNew`, and this could propagate through/leak into subsequent computations, depending on how exactly `MLList.mapM` works. (It seems that the `r` that gets fed to `computeRfl` comes from a `.rewrite` involving the `target`, so it seems plausible to me that mvars from the `target` could at least get assigned. For what it's worth, I did check: `g.rfl` *can* at least assign mvars in the type of `g`.)

Laziness is tricky, so I'm not sure if these are real issues—thought I'd bring it up just in case! :)

Non-problems: we don't update the `mctx` field in the returned `RewriteResult` here, which means that we effectively ignore any assignment which happens here anyway down on lines 219 and 237 when we `setMCtx r.mctx`. Maybe-problems: we *don't* reset the mctx before we `addRewriteSuggestion`s, and I'm not sure how/when the infoview suggestions handle mvar assignments.

I suppose the prudent thing to do would be to change the line to `withoutModifyingState <| withMCtx r.mctx do (← mkFreshExprMVar r.result.eNew).mvarId!.rfl`. (We could also maybe get away with just `withMCtx`, but I'm not sure if there are other parts of the state that need backtracking.) But if this isn't actually an issue, it's of course not worth the extra state-shuffling.

Thanks @thorimur. I've had a look over this, but with limited time right now, I've only added some conservative `withMCtx` and `withoutModifyingState` as you suggested, without actually coming up with good tests for this.

Minor, but is there a reason that `stop_at_rfl` is of type `Bool` but by default a (coerced) `False : Prop` (and snake-cased like a proof instead of a `Bool`)? (Perhaps this isn't the PR to change it in, though.)
Oops, good catches. I'll fix these here.
Should this change be reverted in light of [this comment](https://github.com/leanprover/std4/pull/210/files#r1287827045)?

```suggestion
      pure { r with rfl? := some true }
```
I think we should not update the `mctx` to the post-`rfl` mctx here. I thought about this carefully, and would be happy to expand on it if you'd be interested—but to keep it concise, three facts might be sufficient to show that we shouldn't be doing this:
* this `mctx` remembers the temporary `mvar` that we just made with `mkFreshExprMVar`, which shouldn't exist outside of this "`rfl` simulation".
* when we're feeling lucky, we run `try rfl` *after* setting the mctx. This means we ought to start with an `MCtx` where `rfl` hasn't yet acted.
* likewise, we don't also update `r.result.eNew` or `r.result.eProof` here, and those should stay in lockstep with the `mctx`.
Thanks, I agree.

Github doesn't let me comment or suggest on the appropriate line, but: should we check that (reducible) `rfl` doesn't close the goal by itself before looking at rewrite? (Note that even `rw ... at h` runs `rfl` on the goal and can close it, so checking it is indeed applicable in every case.) For example:
```
example : 0 = 0 by rw? -- Try this: rw [← @Nat.le_zero] -- "no goals"
```
(This is technically orthogonal to this PR, and maybe should be in a different one, but was born out of thinking about `computeRfl`.)

Hmm... I'm not sure here. I agree the behaviour of `rw?` is confusing when you present it with a goal solvable by `rfl`, but I don't think this makes it `rw?`'s job to try `rfl`.

How about we don't modify this behaviour for now, but I'm happy to consider it separately.

```suggestion
def RewriteResult.computeRfl (r : RewriteResult) : MetaM RewriteResult := withReducible do
```
I think we need a `withReducible` in front of this and probably in front of ``evalTactic (← `(tactic| try rfl))`` on line 267 (or simply in front of the whole tactic, but I'm not sure if that would change the behavior somehow). A test:
```
def zero : Nat := 0

example : zero = 0 := by rw? -- Try this: rw [← Nat.zero_eq] -- "no goals"

-- After applying the suggestion:
example : zero = 0 := by rw [← Nat.zero_eq] -- unsolved goals ⊢ zero ≤ 0

-- Contrast with:
example : 0 = 0 := by rw [← Nat.zero_eq] -- (goal closed)
```
Again, maybe for a different PR, but noticed it while thinking about `computeRfl`. :)
Thanks. Fixed, and added test.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore: fix bug in rw?
